Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing shared facilities for archaeological science at the University of Arizona

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund the purchase of a scanning micro X-Ray Fluorescence (Micro-XRF) spectrometer for dendrochemical and other research. The research it enables is significant because it permits scientists to reconstruct multiple aspects of past environments and environmental change over time. Many species of trees add a visibly distinct ring of wood each year. The width of the annual ring may vary substantially from year to year, and these patterns of variation may be sufficiently distinctive to allow wood from a given site to be dated by comparison to a master chronology for the region. Dendrochronology was first developed at the University of Arizona in the 1930's. Once dated, the rings may be used to reconstruct variation in the factors controlling ring width. These include annual rainfall, annual temperature (at high altitude), the frequency of forest fires, and in which region the tree grew. A relatively new science is dendrochemistry - the study of variation in chemical composition from ring to ring within a tree. This award will allow researchers at the University of Arizona to undertake novel dendrochemical research on the enormous archive of cores from modern and ancient wood in the University of Arizona's Laboratory of Tree Ring Research (LTRR). The instrument will also be a valuable tool for LTRR'S outreach work with visiting high school science classes.

The instrument will be installed in LTRR. A priority will be the search for evidence in dated tree rings of former volcanic eruptions and major forest fires, both of which result in spikes of certain chemical elements that are then taken up by growing trees. Since volcanic eruptions often spread ash (microtephra) over a very large area, they offer a potentially valuable means of correlating archaeological and paleoenvironmental sequences across a large region. Dendrochemical analysis by micro-XRF potentially offers a quick and efficient means of detecting and dating these past eruptions. An estimated 30-40,000 wood samples in LTRR cannot currently be assigned a cutting date because the outer ring is indistinct. Pilot research has however shown distinctive chemical changes at the heartwood/sapwood junction in several species, and also in the penultimate ring. Micro-XRF will be used to scan currently undated cores to look for these signals, from which cutting dates can be derived. This research can potentially make available many more dated samples for archaeological and paleoenvironmental interpretation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report

The National Science Foundation’s Archaeology and Archaeometry Program awarded the University of Arizona $200,107 to buy two scientific instruments for shared use in archaeological research. One is a specialized digital camera for photography through microscopes; the other is a scanning micro-X-Ray Fluorescence (µ-XRF) spectrometer. The main goals were to enhance and grow the capacity for interdisciplinary archaeological science research at the University of Arizona. This has been achieved by improving microscope lab facilities which are already part of a thriving program of archaeological science research, and by making µ-XRF available to a broad user community with access to unique archaeological collections at the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research and the Arizona State Museum.


Intellectual merit

Micro-XRF presents numerous ways to advance knowledge through non-destructive exploration of the chemistry of anthropological artifacts. Now in place in newly developed laboratory facilities in the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research Archive Building, the instrument will be used to develop a range of new applications including: (1) scanning selections from the vast Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research (LTRR) archive of archaeological wood (from the SW USA and ancient Mediterranean) to find chemical signatures in tree rings of past volcanic eruptions, forest fires, and terminal growth rings that would provide more exact dates for archaeological events; (2) complementing, and improving the accuracy of, optical petrography of archaeological pottery; (3) undertaking research on the huge archaeological and ethnographic collections of the Arizona State Museum (ASU); and (4) exploring historic artworks and artifacts from the University of Arizona Museum of Art.


Broader impacts

The University of Arizona has the largest number of faculty and staff in the field of archaeological sciences of any university in the USA, and has trained the majority of American researchers in such fields as dendrochronology and geoarchaeology. Many senior researchers and graduate students from other American universities, and many foreign researchers, come to the University of Arizona to work or study with our faculty and staff. The new instrumentation is available (with local expertise in interpretation) to all resident and non-resident archaeological scientists who might benefit by using it, and also to the many archaeologists in private-sector firms around Tucson. The scanning micro-XRF spectrometer will expand the ability of dendroarchaeologists to extract culturally significant information from prehistoric tree rings. The UA tree-ring archive has a starring role in current national policy debates about the periodicity of drought and forest fires in the southwestern USA. This instrument will significantly enhance our ability to interpret that record and to find markers for other events pertinent to societal change. It will create new opportunities for the integrated archaeometric study of ceramics and inform Museum and Native American groups about the degree of heavy metal pesticide contamination on objects subject to repatriation. The user-friendly equipment and diverse range of archeological and ethnographic materials at UA will open up numerous "hands-on" opportunities for experiential learning for graduate students and the visual display of data and other images generated will be utilized for undergraduate learning and K-12 outreach.

 


Summary

 

Key outcomes:

 

Sourcing, delivery, installation and testing of the camera and Micro-XRF

Completion of associated lab infrastructure for the Micro-XRF

Utilization of new equipment for an Ceramic Microscopy Workshop

Successful phase of pilot investigation testing out a range of XRF mapping and line scanning applications on the following materials: Archaeological ceramic thin sections, slags, stone beads, archaeological artifacts, artworks, modern and ancient wood samples. Initiation of new interdisciplinary collabourations for archaeological science.
